There are many different SAP systems that can be analyzed with an SOS and can be referred from the CQC SOS Infosheet

üåüNew in CQC SOS: SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS)!

  • SAP Cloud Identity Services are a group of services of SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), which enable you to integrate identity and access management between systems. 
  • Besides the CQC SOS for SAP BTP, which provides a security assessment of those security-relevant configurations and authorization assignments which are in the responsibility of the customer and focuses on reviewing the platform aspects, a new CQC SOS in the BTP realm is now available:  CQC SOS for CIS. 

The CQC SOS for CIS provides a security assessment structured in the following sections:

  • General Security Status for CIS - e.g. security aspects related to administrator user/system management like critical authorizations and MFA enforcement, the security alert and notification configuration etc.
  • Security Checks for Identity Authentication - e.g. application specific checks like assigned password policy, MFA,   Remember Me functionality etc.

entry.title: Handling High-Frequency message Integration in SAP CPI with SFTP Append Mode Issues
entry.content:
Introduction

Recently we worked on a high-frequency interface using SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to process a continuous stream of IDocs from a source system. The requirement was to map these IDocs, and send the mapped content to a target system using SFTP. All messages needed to be appended to a single file, and that file was picked up and processed by a job every 5 minutes at the target side.

At first glance, this looked like a simple scenario, but it turned out to be a tricky problem due to the way SFTP receiver works in high-frequency situations.

Problem Statement

We received a high volume of IDocs per minute, and our CPI iFlow was designed to do the following:

Map incoming IDocs to the target structure.

Use the SFTP Receiver Adapter and append to write to a single file for 5 mins after this  the downstream job process every 5 minutes. However, the target system experienced significant problems with increased load.

1. NULL characters in random lines.

2. Truncation of data.

Final file was corrupted or incomplete and therefore unusable. Final file was looking like below:

We noted the following:

The SFTP Adapter in Append Mode cannot support concurrent writes. When multiple CPI threads attempted to append concurrently:

  • Some I/O calls overlapped.
  • File locks failed.
  • The content was corrupted (e.g. NULL characters, partial lines).

CPI does not guarantee ordered or transactional writes when multiple messages are attempting to access the SFTP channel at the same time.

Solution:

To resolve the issue, we redesigned the solution as 2 separate iFlows utilizing Data Store.

iFlow 1 - Message Processing and Write to Data Store

This iFlow receives Idoc from the SAP system and after doing the map it stores the file to the DataStore.

 

Iflow step details:

  • Set header and Content: This is used to set custom header and properties required for processing and logging.
  • Message Mapping: here Idoc structure is mapped to the required target structure.
  • Write: The transformed structure is then write to the Data Store for the next step. This structure should be in XML format for the next step to read it.

iFlow 2 ‚Äì Aggregation and SFTP File Upload

This iFlow is triggered by a Timer every 5 minutes. It reads all messages stored earlier by the 1st iFlow.

  • We have used Data Store Select to fetch all unprocessed messages in the interval of 5 mins. We have given the number of messages as 500, so that it will pull all the files written by 1st flow on DataStore.

 "Delete on Completion" This check we have selected such that no file will be processed twice after successful processing of the file.

We have given the Number of polled messages as 500, so that it will pick up all the messages that were stored in datastore during last 5 mins. If any data left it will be processed in next poll.

  • When Select step is picking the file up from the data store it combines all the files in the following structure.

In my case the file was looking as below:

We have used a simple groovy to collect all the data between the tag <data> and appended them to create a CSV file

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Get XML as string
    def body = message.getBody(String)

    // Parse XML using XmlSlurper
    def root = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body)

    // Collect all <data> elements
    def dataLines = root.message.record.data.collect { it.text() }

    // Create CSV string with LF at end
    def csv = dataLines.join("\n") + "\n"

    // Set CSV as new body
    message.setBody(csv)
    return message
}

After the groovy the file looks like as below:

This approach created the file which behaves like Append Mode but in a safe, sequential, and controlled manner.

The resulting content is then sent to the target using the SFTP Receiver Adapter.

In conclusion, this method ensures data integrity, sequential processing, and improved performance by safely simulating append mode of SFTP receiver adapter.
No concurrency issues
No file corruption
Scalable for high-volume scenarios

Thank you.

entry.title: IFRS 18 Explained: What SAP S/4HANA Customers Need to Know Before 2027
entry.content:
Spoiler
 

IFRS 18 introduces one of the biggest changes to financial statement presentation in decades, replacing IAS 1 and redefining how companies structure their Profit and Loss statements. This blog breaks down the new categories, required subtotals, MPM rules, and cash-flow changes in simple, human language ‚Äî and explains how SAP is preparing to support customers across S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, and On-Premise. With comparative reporting for 2026 and mandatory adoption from 2027, now is the time for finance and IT teams to understand what‚Äôs coming and how to prepare their SAP landscape.

What Is IFRS 18 and Why Is It Important?

IFRS 18 is a brand-new reporting standard released by the IASB. It replaces IAS 1 (Presentation of Financial Statements) and becomes effective on January 1, 2027.

In simple terms, IFRS 18 changes how companies present their Income Statement (P&L) and how they explain their financial performance.

Think of it as a cleaner, more structured way to show:

  • Where money comes from
  • Where it goes
  • What part of the business truly drives performance

The goal is to:

  • Make financial statements easier to understand
  • Improve consistency across companies
  • Increase transparency for investors
  • Make comparison between companies more fair and simple

What‚Äôs Changing in the Profit and Loss Statement? 

IFRS 18 completely reorganizes the Profit and Loss (P&L) structure.
Instead of mixing items together, companies must now classify every income and expense into new categories:

New Mandatory Categories

  • Operating: Day-to-day business activities
  • Investing: Returns or costs related to long-term investments
  • Financing: Borrowings, interest, and funding-related items
  • Income Tax: All tax-related items
  • Discontinued Operations: Business operations that are shut down or sold

New Required Subtotals

Companies must show these subtotals:

  • Operating Profit
  • Profit or Loss Before Financing and Income Tax
  • Profit or Loss

This improves clarity and avoids situations where different companies calculate ‚Äúoperating profit‚Äù differently.

What Are Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs)?

IFRS 18 introduces strict rules for something many companies already do:
show custom KPIs like ‚ÄúAdjusted EBITDA,‚Äù ‚ÄúCore Profit,‚Äù or ‚ÄúUnderlying Margin.‚Äù

These are called Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs).

Under IFRS 18, companies MUST:

  • Explain how the measure is calculated
  • Explain why it is useful
  • Provide a reconciliation to an official IFRS subtotal
  • Include this reconciliation in the notes, and it must be audited

This improves trust and transparency around custom metrics that companies use to tell their story.

Changes to the Cash Flow Statement

IFRS 18 also updates IAS 7 (Cash Flow Statements).
Previously, companies had flexibility in classifying certain cash flows.

Under IFRS 18:

  • Dividends paid ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities
  • Interest paid ‚Üí must be shown under Financing activities
  • Interest received ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities

This eliminates the old ‚Äúchoice-based‚Äù method and brings global consistency.

Impact on Financial Reporting and Disclosure

IFRS 18 affects several areas of financial reporting:

P&L Structure

Companies must reorganize their charts of accounts and reporting hierarchies.

Disclosures and Notes

More detail is required, especially around MPMs, aggregation rules, and reconciliation.

Comparative Reporting

Mandatory disclosure of 2026 figures in the new IFRS 18 structure when reporting for 2027.

What Does This Mean for Companies Using SAP?

SAP is currently analysing the full impact of IFRS 18 and consulting with customers through Customer Engagement Initiatives.

Key areas SAP is reviewing include:

  • Functional areas
  • General Ledger structure
  • Valuation processes
  • Reporting frameworks in S/4HANA
  • Group Reporting layouts
  • Cash-flow classifications
  • Universal Journal (ACDOCA) extensibility

SAP expects to release a formal solution approach by December 2025(as documented in SAP Note-https://me.sap.com/notes/3670330/E) . This guidance is expected to be included in the IFRS 18 updates for SAP Group Reporting as part of the 1SG content package.

The solution may differ across editions:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    ‚Üí Expect more standardized, pre-delivered content
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
    ‚Üí More flexibility with governance
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
    ‚Üí Potentially greater configurability

SAP will deliver updates through notes, documentation, and future releases.

How Customers Can Prepare Today

Even before SAP finalizes its solution, companies can begin preparing by:

‚úî Reviewing current P&L structures
‚úî Identifying where income/expense items will map under IFRS 18
‚úî Understanding new disclosure requirements
‚úî Reviewing cash-flow classifications
‚úî Collecting internal MPM definitions
‚úî Engaging with SAP through CEI or Customer Influence Requests

Early preparation will make the transition smoother when IFRS 18 becomes mandatory.

Conclusion

IFRS 18 represents a major shift in how companies communicate their financial performance. The new structure, required subtotals, stricter rules for custom KPIs, and updates to cash flow presentation will significantly impact both finance teams and system configurations.

As outlined in SAP Note 3670330, SAP is developing a comprehensive solution targeted for late 2025, with further updates expected as IFRS 18 continues to evolve. In my view, this is the right time for organizations to start understanding the new requirements, assess their current data and reporting structures, and begin preparing their SAP landscapes for a smooth transition.

More updates will come as SAP refines its roadmap ‚Äî stay tuned.

entry.title: New Security Optimization Service for Cloud Connector
entry.content:
Security and the protection of your systems have become more important than ever and play a crucial role in today‚Äôs business environment.

The SAP Security Optimization Service (SOS) is designed to analyze, verify, and improve the security of your SAP system by identifying potential security risks and providing recommendations to mitigate these risks within the assessed systems. 

There are many different SAP systems that can be analyzed with an SOS and can be referred from the CQC SOS Infosheet

üåüNew in CQC SOS: Cloud Connector!

What is the Cloud Connector?

  • Serves as a link between SAP BTP applications and on-premises systems.
  • Runs as on-premises agent in a secured network.
  • Provides fine-grained control over On-premises systems and resources that can be accessed by cloud applications and Cloud applications using the Cloud Connector.
  • Besides the CQC SOS for SAP BTP , which provides a security assessment of those security-relevant configurations and authorization assignments which are in the responsibility of the customer and focuses on reviewing the platform aspects, a new CQC SOS in the BTP realm is now available:  CQC SOS for Cloud Connector. 

The CQC SOS for Cloud Connector provides a security assessment structured in the following sections:

  • General Security Status for Master Instance: security aspects related to the versions of Cloud Connector and underlying JDK, certificates, enabled encryption ciphers for HTTPS connections to the administration UI, trust configurations etc. 
  • General Security Status for Shadow Instance: contains a subset of the ‚ÄúGeneral Security Status for Master Instance‚Äù section which is applicable for the connected shadow instance.
  • Subaccount-Specific Security Status: settings for connected subaccounts like encrypted communication with backend systems, access policies for HTTP and RFC connections as well as audit log and log/trace configurations.

entry.title: How far will AI go... and what will it mean for your job?
entry.content:
In April this year, I decided to voluntarily retire early from SAP after 6 years of a very interesting journey. Indeed, I've lived from the inside the infusion of powerful Artificial Intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, for application development and for process automation.

Since then, I've spent 8 months observing the IT industry evolution, particularly around AI. And now, I have very mixed feelings:

‚úîÔ∏è On one hand, I'm impressed how well SAP is positioned on the market and how SAP AI is powerful

‚ùì On the other hand, I'm more and more worried by the impact humanoid robots and AI, from SAP and all vendors, will have on so many jobs everywhere.

So I decided to share my views with you in this blog post.

SAP is amazingly well positioned with Business AI

A month ago I watched SAP TechEd Keynote and also a few sessions, and I have to say that I'm impressed. By the way, in case you missed it, watch the replay of the keynote:

I discovered AI more than 40 years ago, when I was studying to graduate in 1986 as an engineer in computing science, and 10 years ago I was working for Antidot, a french startup involved in knowledge graphs, where I wrote this white paper on Business Knowledge Graphs in 2014.

So, from my humble point of view, putting together SAP ERP + SAP Business Data Cloud + SAP Knowledge Graphs + SAP Business AI with Joule creates a winning combo. It puts SAP in a unique position , better than any competitor, to bring the best of AI to the customers.

And what has been presented and announced at SAP TechEd makes SAP even stronger:

SAP-ABAP-1 is a new model allowing to handle ABAP language: trained on more than 250 million lines of ABAP code, 30 million lines of CDS code, and extensive technical documentation, it is purpose-built to explain and generate modern ABAP code.

SAP-RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1) is a brand new classification and regression model, allowing to better handle structured, tabular business data. It is a paradigm shift in machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance and already outperforms regular text-based LLMs through semantic understanding of tabular relationships.

Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud is an RDF graph built from system catalog, capturing tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It providesthe semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning. It allows agents to reason about data, to understand entities relationships, and which attributes are relevant. 

A2A and MCP protocols foster Agentic AI by allowing autonomous agents collaboration: SAP is providing out-of-the-box Joule agents and alllowing customers to create custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio. Beyond that, agentic protocols such as A2A - Agent to Agent - and MCP - Model Context Protocol - with SAP Lean IX Agent Hub and Agent Mining in SAP Signavio allow to standardize, deploy and monitor AI agents collaboration.

To dig deeper on these topics, follow the links I've put in the text above, watch the replay of the SAP TechEd sessions and also refer to

  • SAP  Innovation Guide
  • SAP Guide "What is Joule?" 

What impact will AI have on human employment?

So, we all agree, SAP is doing very well with Business AI for empowering companies to do better and faster. And this is very good for SAP and its entire ecosystem.

But when it comes to employees working in these companies, things could be different. Indeed, some news popping up in mainstream media are a bit worrying. For instance, according to McKinsey & Company, AI can already do almost 60% of all the work:

Their research ‚ÄúAgents, robots, and us: Skill partnerships in the age of AI‚Äù says that the future of work will be basically shaped by partnerships among people, agents, and robots - all powered by AI. The research emphasizes that capturing AI‚Äôs massive potential economic value - about $2.9 trillion by 2023 in the US only! - depends entirely on how organizations will reorganize.

Indeed, be it for business users, for consultants, for developers, AI agents will be everywhere... and they will do a lot of tasks done by human employees today.

And we have already seen this year how big tech firms have "reorganized" to embrace AI benefits: 

  • Amazon - 30,000 layoffs
  • Accenture - 11,000 layoffs
  • Microsoft - 6,000 layoffs
  • HP - 4,000-6000 layoffs

So in total more than 50,000 jobs have been erased in a few months only. And SAP as well is shrinking its workforce: ‚ÄúIn one year, it could be one or sometimes two percent of jobs that are eliminated‚Äù said Christian Klein, and Dominik Asam  added ‚ÄúThere are certain tasks which are automated and for the same volume of output we can afford to have less people". He admits to be "brutal",  comparing this program to routines such as brushing teeth...

Meanwhile, it seems everyone is trying to reassure the public that everything will be fine‚Ä¶ perhaps to prevent tens of millions of workers from becoming upset about the prospect of losing their jobs?

Should not a part of the value created by all the AI software and humanoid robots be used to compentiate this massive loss of jobs?

Today, in many countries, health insurance, unemployment insurance, and pensions are financed by contributions paid by employers and employees on human work. If the number of employees is decreasing, shouldn't social security contributions be levied on the work performed by AI agents and humanoid robots?

Will robots embrace Karl Marx slogan? üôÉ

What do you think? How do you envision the impact AI and robots will have on your job in 3, 5 or 10 years?

Your feedback will be highly appreciated, so feel free to share your own views in the comments!

entry.title: Prompt Engineering: Unlocking Hidden Power for Enterprise AI Success
entry.content:
Gaps in Prompt Design Derail the User Experience

What happens when gaps in prompt design or user intent recognition turns everyday AI interactions into a dead‚Äëend waste of time?

Have you ever experienced this type of situation?

For example, I recently tried to claim a rebate for a kitchen appliance, but the company‚Äôs AI assistant misinterpreted my request and left me stuck with irrelevant FAQs. The issue was poor prompt design. With proper prompt engineering, the assistant could have recognized my rebate request and guided me to the correct, enabled form. A smarter workflow would have turned a dead end into a faster way to get my rebate money.

What fun!

This experience underscores a critical truth: when prompts fail to capture real‚Äëworld users‚Äô intent, the customer experience collapses.

For business and IT users working with AI, this isn‚Äôt just a consumer inconvenience, it‚Äôs a wake‚Äëup call. Prompt engineering is more than a technical capability; it‚Äôs the discipline of shaping interactions so that AI systems understand nuance, adapt to context, and deliver meaningful results.

Whether in customer service troubleshooting, enterprise workflows (agentic AI), or customer engagement, the quality of prompts directly determines the quality of the user experience.

In this age of AI agents and assistants, refining prompts is no longer optional; it is essential for building trust, driving efficiency, enabling scalable automation, and achieving successful outcomes.

Reducing AI Project Failures - Understanding Prompt Engineering

Prompt engineering is the art and science of designing inputs that guide AI models to produce desired outputs. By framing instructions accurately, organizations can harness AI to generate relevant, high-quality responses.

According to a RAND report, 80% of AI project failures stem from poor human to AI communication. Misunderstandings between business and IT teams about goals, data, and capabilities are the most common cause of failure. Companies that master prompt engineering achieve significantly higher ROI compared to those relying on basic or ad hoc prompting (1).

In short: success doesn‚Äôt come from the technology alone; it comes from how we communicate with it.

Why It Matters

Prompt engineering is no longer a fringe capability and skill. It is becoming a critical organizational capability embedded into everyday business functions.

According to Market Research Future (MRFR), the prompt engineering market was valued at $2.195 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow to $32.78 billion by 2035, with a staggering 27.86% CAGR (2).

SAP Prompt Engineering Adoption

Prompt engineering transforms vague queries into precise instructions, guiding AI toward accurate, consistent, and actionable outputs. With AI agents and assistants like SAP‚Äôs Joule, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, and OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT, organizations recognize that prompt engineering is essential to maximize AI‚Äôs potential and align outcomes with business goals.

SAP has embedded prompt engineering into Joule, powered by the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and Launchpad (part of the SAP Business Technology Platform) and supported by SAP‚Äôs AI Foundation, delivering enterprise‚Äëgrade accuracy and trust with Large Language Models (LLMs).

At SAP Sapphire 2025, SAP announced a proprietary Prompt Optimizer built with the company, Not Diamond. This optimizer enables enterprises to migrate and adapt prompts across multiple LLMs, supporting consistency, accelerating adoption, and improving the user experience across diverse AI systems (3).

Not Diamond envisions ‚Äúa multi‚Äëmodel AI future, with thousands of foundation models, millions of fine‚Äëtuned variants, and billions of custom inference engines running on top of them.‚Äù Their infrastructure routes, governs, and scales prompts across these systems, ensuring flexibility and trust.

This partnership confirms prompt engineering as an important, core enterprise requirement, bridging business strategy with technology capabilities for responsible AI.

Best of Prompt Engineering Capabilities

Prompt engineering serves as the strategic layer that transforms raw AI capabilities into business value, delivering a range of benefits including:

  1. Clarifies Intent ‚Äì Ensures AI understands user goals, reducing miscommunication and aligning outputs with business needs.
  2. Customer Engagement & Personalization ‚Äì Crafts prompts that drive tailored chatbot interactions, outreach, and recommendations, fostering loyalty and satisfaction.
  3. Structures Outputs ‚Äì Guides AI to deliver usable formats (tables, lists, reports, narratives) for clarity and consistency.
  4. Improves Efficiency & Operational Automation ‚Äì Minimizes unnecessary token usage, accelerates turnaround, and empowers agentic AI to automate repetitive workflows such as reporting, summarization, and FAQ handling.
  5. Adds Domain Context ‚Äì Embeds industry‚Äëspecific language, governance and compliance rules, approved product names, synonyms, and brand tone for relevance.
  6. Supports Scalability Across Teams ‚Äì Builds reusable prompt libraries and frameworks that allow consistent enterprise‚Äëwide adoption without reinventing workflows.
  7. Content Quality & Consistency ‚Äì Ensures outputs are brand‚Äëaligned, accurate, and emotionally resonant across all channels.
  8. Optimizes Across Models ‚Äì With tools like Not Diamond‚Äôs Prompt Optimizer, prompts can be migrated and adapted across Copilot, Gemini, ChatGPT, Joule, and other LLMs.
  9. Enhanced Accuracy & Decision‚ÄëMaking ‚Äì Produces precise, consistent outputs and extracts actionable intelligence quickly to support better business decisions.

By uniting these capabilities, prompt engineering becomes the foundation for trustworthy, scalable, and business‚Äëaligned AI success.

Short on Time? Who Manages Prompt Engineering

Prompt engineering isn‚Äôt just the domain of IT or developers; business roles like product managers, business analysts, marketing, communications, operations, UX/CX designers, content strategists, and other lines of business are equally critical.

For example, product managers align prompts with business goals, analysts map workflows, designers ensure intuitive user experiences, and strategists refine language and tone. Together, they make AI outputs reliable and customer‚Äëcentric.

Also, a dedicated, focused part‚Äëtime prompt engineering consultant can help jumpstart this process by auditing the current status, delivering best practices, and establishing governance standards in collaboration with IT and key stakeholders.

In a fast paced, short-handed, busy work environment, these prompt optimization specialists can provide support by providing focus and discipline, coaching key stakeholders with standard operation procedures (SOPs), monitoring performance, and refining prompts as business needs evolve to help ensure AI systems remain accurate, consistent, and trusted across the enterprise.

Final Thoughts

Prompt engineering is no longer a niche skill or technical curiosity; it has become a core business capability that drives efficiency, compliance, and innovation. Organizations that embrace it gain a competitive edge, while those that neglect it risk wasted investments and inconsistent results.

By embedding prompt engineering as a business standard, integrated into workflows through enterprise‚Äëwide libraries, governance, and automated refinement, companies can optimize AI strategies to keep pace with evolving models, regulations, and customer expectations.

The future of enterprise AI will not be defined by those who merely explore prompts, but by those who master them, transforming raw model potential into trusted, scalable business value.

And as a result, users can save time by getting answers versus gaps and dead ends.

entry.title: How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes
entry.content:
How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes

Read the original article here

Expectations of the potential impact of AI have never been higher. But so far, most projects have only produced incremental improvements in isolated areas. So, what do you have to do to get AI to deliver material change across your business? The answer lies in preparing your processes and data‚Äîgetting them into a condition where AI can use them to deliver on its promise of radical transformation. In this thought provoking article, two AI experts from SAP explain what‚Äôs involved, where to get started, and which SAP solutions can help you really put AI to work.

About the authors:

J√ºrgen Butsmann is part of the SAP Cloud ERP Product Marketing team responsible for AI in the context of SAP S/4HANA, finance and digital supply chain. J√ºrgen has been with SAP for more than 26 years.  He is a recognized expert for SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP .

Terry Penner is part of the SAP BTP product marketing team, focused on SAP BTP for Cloud ERP. He has more than 25 years of technical and business experience in the SAP platform and analytics, including working directly on hundreds of customer implementations and presenting on SAP technology topics at conferences around the world.

 

The challenges in reaching AI‚Äôs potential

Business leaders believe AI has the potential to transform their organizations.  They see it accelerating cycle times, reducing errors, performing processes automatically, and yielding insights. Their initial experiments and projects have reinforced this expectation by delivering productivity improvements, albeit in isolated areas.

However, return on investment has so far been disappointing and IT teams are finding it challenging to scale AI beyond point solutions. They‚Äôre also nervous for ethical and security reasons about exposing their proprietary business data to public large language  models (LLMs).

Observations from customers

The discussions we‚Äôve been having with SAP customers have revealed these common challenges IT leaders face in realizing AI‚Äôs potential.

  • Insecure architecture. Using public LLMs alone is not always reliable. AI really needs to use the organization‚Äôs own business data. But exposing corporate data to LLMs raises security and ethical issues.
  • Fragmented systems. Applying AI to a process that is contained within a single system is relatively easy. But most real business processes span multiple departments and systems. Often these applications and their data are not integrated which prevents AI from carrying out business processes end to end.
  • No single semantic layer. Enterprise applications today, whether SAP or non-SAP, all have differences in their data structures. Data transformation and harmonization are necessary to allow the sharing of transactional data, and for analytical processes and AI functions to  take place.
  • One-way data transformation. Data warehousing, as practiced by SAP and by other vendors in the past, focused on extraction  and one-way transformation, storage, and processing of data, decoupled from original data structures and business process context. Effective, enterprise-wide AI, however, requires two-way transformation and re-integration of data into business processes as they run.

What organizations need

AI agent networks need a solid data foundation  if they are to process queries across systems effectively. The organization‚Äôs data structures‚Äîits master data and system architecture‚Äîneed to be harmonized so AI can understand the different systems in a consistent and accurate way.

When processes are integrated, consistent data can be stored in the systems. Integrating systems and maintaining consistent data will overcome the problem of isolated, fragmented systems and allow AI to execute end-to-end business processes.

 

SAP‚Äôs strategy for scalable AI

SAP‚Äôs approach to enabling organizations to scale their use of AI is to facilitate the integration of systems and business processes, and the harmonization of business data, within a secure AI architecture.

The key components of this are:

  • Secure AI architecture
  • Solutions for scaling AI
  • Joule, the integrated digital assistant
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for data harmonization
  • SAP Business Technology Platform as the platform for Joule, SAP BDC, AI Hub, and process

Secure AI architecture

Figure 1: A common sub-optimal approach

Figure 2: Exposing corporate data to LLMs is not recommended

Figure 3: How to allow AI to understand your business safely

SAP's secure architecture allows AI to understand your business safely.

The process works like this:

  • The user queries their digital assistant, Joule.
  • The digital assistant uses both the LLM and the vector database to create a refined prompt. The technical process is decoupled from the proprietary business data (a technique known as masking) to prevent the data being exposed outside the organization.
  • The refined prompt then requests data from cloud ERP and other proprietary systems, such as the  SAP Foundation Model.
  • Data is returned to the digital assistant via the vector database and the results are clustered and explained by the LLM.
  • The digital assistant then presents the final answer to the user.

 

SAP solutions for scaling AI

As an SAP customer, you may be familiar with our strategic architecture. Working from the top down, we call out here three elements which are material to scaling AI.

Figure 4: SAP strategic architecture

Joule

Joule is SAP‚Äôs agent orchestrator and ubiquitous user interface for AI. It is embedded throughout SAP Business Suite solutions incl. SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private. Joule skills perform simple repetitive tasks within one application. Joule Agents give context-aware access to a system  of AI agents, that can perform more complex end-to-end processes across multiple systems‚Äî provided those systems have been integrated and their data‚Äôs been harmonized.

Agents can work within or separately from Joule. They can call and quest other agents in the background without having to be triggered manually. This is done transparently in Joule to keep the human in the loop.

SAP Business Technology Platform

SAP Business Technology Platform supports SAP Business Suite solutions. It provides a foundation for AI and data analytics and includes integration and extension solutions.

  • SAP Integration Suite contains more than 3,800 prebuilt integrations and APIs for connecting business processes across systems more easily.
  • SAP Build solutions help you create extensions and automate processes across SAP and  non-SAP solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a single semantic layer across applications and enables the harmonization of data. This is essential not only for AI to work effectively, but also to share transactional data and facilitate analytical processes. SAP BDC uses data products which are prebuilt multi-layered structures (which may include extensions of clean-core compliant data structures) for executing function-specific queries and processes across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Having a common data platform across your enterprise allows AI to utilize your proprietary  business data within a secure environment. The data products come as part of so-called intelligent applications which contains applications built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, as well as other domain content.

Customers can always extend the data layer, for example by defining custom data products.

Advantages of SAP Business Data Cloud

In some cases, operational data has been used for executing AI functions or analytical and planning operations without applying data products from SAP BDC. In the past, data storage for these operations took place in BTP, as the AI hub is located there as well as in SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA. But what was missing was the delivery of a common and harmonized data storage concept across all SAP applications.

SAP BDC makes it possible to establish a common architecture where data is extracted, transformed, and returned to SAP Business Suite applications, creating harmonized data storage. A common data platform across your organization will provide the data foundation for AI to connect securely to specialized, enterprise-specific data.

SAP BDC also allows for SAP-managed deployment, maintenance, and facilitation of data processing and transformation from the source system to SAP BDC. These services are part of the data products of the intelligent applications.

SAP Business Suite provides APIs between different SAP and non-SAP applications, allowing the data exchange needed for integrated execution of business processes.

Prioritizing the establishment of a common layer also influences changes to local data structures. The data required to support integrated business process and other cross-system operations is held directly within the source systems, with no need for a secondary harmonization layer. This is very well aligned with the clean core concept.

 

What does it mean for me?

Do I need all this before my AI will work?

No, but the more elements you have, the more value you get.

  • If you only have SAP BDC, you‚Äôll have access to harmonized data‚Äîbut you won‚Äôt yet have connected business processes across applications.
  • If you use SAP BTP solutions such as SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build to create integrations and extensions, you‚Äôll be able to join up business processes across applications‚Äîbut not harmonize their data.
  • If you use SAP BDC and SAP BTP solutions together, you can integrate business processes across systems and harmonize their data. A derived harmonization model is intended to be generated by the system using APIs to produce a fully integrated model for cross-system reporting and AI data usage. Then Joule Agents can use that harmonized data to orchestrate end-to-end business processes across multiple systems automatically.

Are there other ways of doing this?

Yes, but they‚Äôre not as good. Some of our customers use third party data harmonization solutions for cross-system analytical use cases.

The difference with SAP‚Äôs AI-first strategy is that it is always aware of the actual business context and reintegrates results data back into the business process. This is essential if AI agents are to make use of that data in cross-department, cross-system use cases.

SAP‚Äôs integrated suite of ERP and business applications, together with our data management solution, and our integration and extension solutions, is unique in the marketplace at present.

How can I move from isolated use cases to enterprise-wide AI?

Basically, you need to offer AI that people can trust.

To achieve trust, you need a secure AI architecture along with integrated processes and harmonized data. When you have these, people will trust the AI model. Then they‚Äôll come to view it as reliable and adopt it for day-to-day, end-to-end business processes across the organization.

 

How this approach can help you - a worked example

Automating financial close

One of the most attractive use cases for AI is to modernize a business process which occurs in every business and which, if automated, would deliver significant productivity and cost benefits. The process in question is the financial close.

It‚Äôs a classic challenge. The data required sits in multiple systems, such as ERP, CRM, tax engines, and payroll‚Äîwhich aren‚Äôt integrated. The data is also in incompatible formats. Both these mean that considerable manual work is required in extracting and reconciling the data. All of which adds up to time, cost, and stress at the end of every accounting period.

With systems integrated using SAP Integration Suite, and data harmonized using SAP Business Data Cloud, Joule Agents can be built to help perform financial close processes optimally‚Äîalways leaving knowledgeable human beings to make the final decision.

SAP‚Äôs enablers of autonomous finance can expedite financial close processes and deliver material cost savings. The Canadian energy company, Suncor, achieved a reduction of US$20,000 in month-end closing costs and a 98% reduction in time to reconcile ICT postings using SAP Business AI and SAP Build Process Automation.

Figure 5: Integration flow diagram of a connected financial close process in SAP Integration Suite.

 

How do I get started?

To summarize, our two key recommendations are to modernize your data and integrate your processes.

Modernize your data

Evolve your data strategy from using harmonized historical data extracted from business systems, to using current data generated in the process of executing business processes.

Aim to make multiple data sources accessible to AI, including a combination of business data from multiple internal systems and external data.

Integrate your processes

Move away from older integration technologies that are not cloud aware, such as process integration or process orchestration, to standardizing on SAP Integration Suite with thousands of prebuilt integrations.

Adopt a consistent method across the organization for connecting your processes so that when you build AI agents to orchestrate them across multiple systems, users get a consistent experience.

 

Immediate next steps

Ask your SAP account manager to set up a conversation with one of our enterprise architects. You can discuss where you are now, where you want to be, and draw up a plan for getting there.

In the meantime, find out more about:

  • SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP‚Äôs vision for autonomous finance

entry.title: How to verify the Swiss E-ID on the SAP Business Technology Platform
entry.content:
How to verify the Swiss E-ID on the SAP Business Technology Platform

Switzerland is progressing with its new state-operated E-ID, branded swiyu, built on decentralization, privacy-by-design, and open standards. This new solution ensures the privacy design with a system where identity data stays on the user‚Äôs device, verification happens peer-to-peer, and the entire infrastructure is publicly governed.
While the official release of the Swiss E-ID is scheduled for summer 2026, the E-ID excites many customers, being the hot topic not only for the public sector in Switzerland but also E-Commerce shops for age checks and customers regulated by the ‚ÄúKnow Your Customer‚Äù guidelines.

Business Relevance

In recruiting, the identity of a new hire is a key information not only in regulated industries. Some products may only be sold to customers of a certain age or to customers which are identified. Some processes ‚Äúdigitize‚Äù the physical ID-Card or Passport using Video, other processes depend on the holder of the ID to show it physically to an agent. As all that is in an ID is data, finding better ways of handling this data should be easy?
However, having a trusted form of identification in the digital era is not as straightforward as one might think. Today, many companies are forced to use external identity validation services including video calls for a Face-to-Face verification. Those services come with high costs and disrupt the smooth user experience for the end consumer.
A trusted digital identification would solve those challenges which the E-ID aims to become. With swiyu, Swiss organizations and citizens will have a compelling solution in their hands ‚Äì ready for integration in their existing processes. SAP Switzerland wants to help its customers in this process for a simple and seamless integration.

Architecture

For the E-ID verification 3 main components are necessary: the E-ID of the consumer, the webpage where the verification process is presented and the verifier ensuring the authenticity, validity, and trust. The E-ID is stored in the digital wallet (swiyu app) on the personal smartphone of the end user. The generic verifier, an open-source application provided by the swiss government, is hosted by the company initiating the verification process. It ensures the trusted communication with the public government registry using anonymized records of the issued IDs.

What is needed for an implementation?

Knowing how the E-ID verification works in theory is nice but of little use if not used in practice. To have a verification with the E-ID in place the generic verifier application needs to be hosted and publicly accessible. The docker image provided by the government can be used to have it up and running in no time. The company running this verifier then needs to put its trust anker in the government registry to be recognized as a valid verifier. Then the webpage needs to integrate to the generic verifier. This integration allows the generation the QR Code and (once the consumer approved the validation request) receiving the results from the E-ID login.

The steps on how to perform this on SAP Business Technology Platform are outlined below.

Setting Up Your Own Verifier on SAP BTP

Setting up the Generic swiyu Verifier on SAP BTP is straightforward: it involves a registration on the e-portal of the Federal Office of Information Technology, Systems and Telecommunication (FOITT), generating a Decentralized Identifier (DID), and deploying to SAP BTP.

Prerequisites:

  • Cloud foundry space
  • PostgreSQL Entitlement

Register on the swiyu Base & Trust Registry

Before starting the technical setup, you register on the swiyu Base & Trust

  1. Register your business or yourself on the e-portal and save the Business Partner ID for later.
  2. Navigate to the API Self-Service Portal:
    1. In the Applications tab, create a new application.
    2. After creation, select the application and subscribe to the Identifier and Status APIs.
    3. Save the Access Token, Refresh Token, and other credentials for later use.

Create a DID and Identifier Space

  1. Using your Business Partner ID and Access Token, request a DID space on the Identifier Registry. Save the Identifier Registry URL and ID for the next steps.
  2. Clone the swiyu DID Toolbox from GitHub and run it with your Identifier Registry URL to create a new DID.
  3. Save the output. The returned array contains your DID and other verification/authentication details.
  4. Store the entire output as a string in the created Identifier Space using the obtained details.

Optional: To become a trusted participant (i.e., to display the ‚Äúverified‚Äù badge when verifying credentials), register for the Trust Registry. Details can be found on the organizations page in the e-portal.

Deploy the Verifier to SAP BTP

  1. In the BTP Cockpit, start a dedicated PostgreSQL instance. The smallest tier is sufficient as the DB only holds cache data.
  2. After provisioning, create a service key to obtain authentication details for the verifier service.
  3. On your local machine, create a manifest.yml file specifying the name, instance, memory, and environment variables (see documentation).
    • When deploying only with the Docker file, you must host your verifier metadata file separately to allow the service to access it.
  4. Push the application using the Cloud Foundry CLI.

You have now deployed the Generic Verifier to SAP BTP and created an API service for verifying VCs on the swiyu Trust Infrastructure. 

‚ÄÉ

Accessing and Securing the API

Access your APIs via the built-in Swagger UI at: <your-server-url>/swagger-ui.html
Optionally, secure the management API endpoints using a fixed asymmetric key or an OAuth2.0 Server.
Note: This process is intended for PoC and familiarization purposes. For full production deployment, check out the deployment considerations here.

Optional: Frontend Integration
In our PoC, we also created a frontend service using UI5 and CAP to integrate JWT authentication with the Verifier Service. This makes it easier for users to interact with and test the service.

Verifying credentials

Screenshot of Credential-Check on the swiyu AppThe process of verifying credentials from a wallet begins when the wallet user scans an offer QR code. This QR code must contain a (deep-)link, which you generate through an API call to the management API of your verifier service.
After scanning the QR code, the wallet holder is prompted to either accept or decline the verification request (see figure 1). If the user accepts, the requested details are sent to the verifier service. These verification results can then be retrieved either by polling the service or by receiving them through a webhook callback.

 

 

Conclusion

You have now deployed and configured the generic swiyu verifier on SAP BTP, registered on the swiyu trust registry, created a DID/identifier space, and enabled QR-based credential verification (with an optional UI5/CAP frontend and basic security options).
Based on this, integration in business processes can replace costly external identity checks by enabling seamless, privacy-preserving E-ID verification for recruiting, age checks, KYC flows and other customer-facing processes while keeping identity data on the user‚Äôs device and relying on the public trust registry.

In a next step, we will explore how to issue certificates, including creating verifiable credentials, the issuer workflow, required registry entries and production-grade deployment. Stay tuned!

Special Thanks goes to Matthias Beeler for developing the PoC and helping create this Blog post, but also Alex Finger, Michael Kaczalak and Patric Imark for driving the topic!

entry.title: SAP to Collaborate with AWS to bring the SAP BTP ABAP Environment to Arm-Based AWS Graviton
entry.content:
Authors: Steven Jones (AWS), Sonja Li√©nard (SAP)

The key to SAP‚Äôs innovation and adoption success has always been its openness, supporting diverse hardware platforms, networks, and technology ecosystems, while offering flexible deployment options for customers operating in mixed and heterogeneous environments. This principle extends to the ABAP Platform and especially the BTP ABAP Environment, which powers next-generation ABAP Cloud applications and extensions. Beyond this openness, SAP is leveraging innovative technologies like AWS's ARM-based Graviton processors. Today, we are excited to announce the evolution of that partnership:

SAP and AWS will collaborate to bring the SAP BTP ABAP environment to Arm-based AWS Graviton processors.

 

A Longstanding History of Co-Innovation in the Cloud

Since 2008, SAP partnered with AWS to help customers leverage cloud innovations. In 2023, we announced that SAP HANA Cloud runs on AWS Graviton, a custom-built chip by AWS that delivers price, performance, and energy efficiency benefits for cloud workloads. By initially migrating SAP HANA Cloud to AWS Graviton3-based Amazon EC2 instances, SAP has seen up to 30% better compute performance for analytical workloads and lowered its compute carbon footprint by an estimated 45%. Building on these experiences, SAP and AWS have been continuously innovating to further improve the performance of SAP HANA Cloud.

Driving Flexibility and Performance

SAP BTP ABAP environment is the platform as a service offering for ABAP developers. It‚Äôs a cloud-optimized ABAP platform based on SAP HANA Cloud that serves as a development and runtime environment for cloud applications.

Initial tests have shown positive results for ABAP on AWS Graviton architectures, demonstrating strong performance and efficiency gains. With the extensive breadth of Amazon EC2 instance families available on Arm, SAP will be able to select the right instance type and size optimized for ABAP workloads and leverage this diverse portfolio for maximum instance flexibility for our customers.

Why Arm and AWS Graviton?

With AWS Graviton3-based instances, SAP experienced up to 35% price-performance improvement for analytics workloads, and a reduction of the compute carbon footprint of SAP HANA Cloud workloads. With AWS Graviton4-based instances, we‚Äôve seen an up to 25% additional performance improvement for analytical and up to 40% additional improvement for transactional workloads compared to AWS Graviton3-based instances.

Now, with the next AWS Graviton5-based Amazon EC2 M9g instances, we‚Äôve observed a 35-60% increase in the performance of our OLTP queries on SAP HANA Cloud in a single generation. Based on the performance improvements demonstrated in SAP HANA Cloud with AWS Graviton processors, SAP is confident the SAP BTP ABAP environment will also leverage AWS Graviton technology to deliver similar benefits.

A Strategic Partnership for Sustainability

This new collaboration continues our shared commitment to sustainability. SAP is a signatory of Amazon‚Äôs Climate Pledge and has accelerated its own sustainability commitment to 2030. Our journey with AWS Graviton aligns perfectly with those goals, and we are eager to see what additional improvements in energy efficiency we can realize together in the future.

What‚Äôs Next?

Porting the SAP BTP ABAP environment to AWS Graviton involves adapting its cloud-native architecture, including containerized services and runtime components, to Arm. SAP and AWS teams will continue developing, testing, and working on performance optimization pipelines to ensure a seamless experience for customers.

We look forward to sharing more updates on this project and the value it brings in terms of performance, reliability, and sustainability. Stay tuned as we continue this journey together.

entry.title: RAG vs CAG: Choosing the Right Knowledge Augmentation Strategy for LLMs
entry.content:
Cache-Augmented Generation offers a compelling alternative to RAG's retrieval pipeline‚Äîeliminating latency overhead and achieving up to 40x faster generation times‚Äîbut context window constraints limit its applicability to smaller, static knowledge bases. For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the choice hinges on a fundamental trade-off: CAG delivers superior speed and slightly higher accuracy for manageable datasets, while RAG remains the only viable option for enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic, evolving knowledge. The emergence of hybrid architectures in 2024-2025 now enables organizations to capture the benefits of both approaches through intelligent query routing

 

Introduction

Large Language Models have transformed how organizations interact with information, but their static training data creates a fundamental limitation: they cannot access current information or proprietary knowledge bases. This knowledge gap has driven the development of augmentation techniques that extend LLM capabilities by grounding responses in external data sources.

Retrieval-Augmented Generation emerged in 2020 as the dominant paradigm, combining information retrieval with text generation to enable LLMs to answer questions using custom document collections. The RAG ecosystem has since matured substantially, spawning an entire ecosystem of vector databases, embedding models, and orchestration frameworks. Yet according to industry analyses, approximately 72% of enterprise RAG implementations either fail outright or deliver significantly below expectations in their first year [1], prompting researchers to explore alternatives.

Cache-Augmented Generation represents a paradigm shift introduced in late 2024. Rather than retrieving relevant documents at query time, CAG preloads entire knowledge bases into the LLM's extended context window and caches the computational state for reuse across queries. This approach eliminates the retrieval pipeline entirely, promising simpler architectures and faster response times. Understanding when to deploy RAG, CAG, or hybrid approaches has become essential for organizations building knowledge-intensive AI applications.

 

What is RAG?

Retrieval-Augmented Generation is an AI framework that enhances Large Language Models by combining information retrieval with text generation. Instead of relying solely on knowledge encoded during training, RAG retrieves relevant information from external knowledge bases at inference time and incorporates it into the generation process.

The foundational paper, "Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Knowledge-Intensive NLP Tasks," was published by Patrick Lewis and collaborators at Facebook AI Research (now Meta AI) in May 2020 [2]. The researchers combined a pre-trained parametric memory (the seq2seq model BART) with non-parametric memory (a dense vector index of Wikipedia), demonstrating state-of-the-art results on open-domain question-answering tasks.

 

 

 

Core Architecture and Workflow

RAG systems operate through two distinct phases. The indexing phase occurs offline before any queries are processed: documents are loaded from various sources, broken into smaller chunks, converted into vector embeddings using models like OpenAI's text-embedding-3-small, and stored in vector databases such as SAP HANA. This preprocessing transforms unstructured documents into a searchable semantic index.

The inference phase activates when users submit queries. The system converts the query into a vector embedding using the same model that processed the documents, searches the vector database for semantically similar chunks, ranks the retrieved results by relevance, and constructs an augmented prompt combining the original query with retrieved context. The LLM then generates a response grounded in the provided information. A typical prompt structure instructs the model: "Using the CONTEXT provided, answer the QUESTION. Keep your answer grounded in the facts of the CONTEXT. If the CONTEXT doesn't contain the answer, say you don't know."

The RAG ecosystem has matured substantially since 2020. Orchestration frameworks like LangChain and LlamaIndex simplify pipeline construction.

 

Issues and Drawbacks of RAG

Despite widespread adoption, RAG systems face significant challenges across latency, accuracy, implementation complexity, and operational maintenance that explain the high enterprise failure rate.

 

Latency Overhead Compounds with Each Component

RAG introduces substantial performance penalties. Research published in December 2024 found that RAG-unique components account for 36-45% of end-to-end latency, with retrieval alone comprising 41% of response time [3]. In aggressive retrieval configurations, RAG overhead can reach 97% of total latency, pushing response times to approximately 30 seconds [3].

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Undermines Long-Context Retrieval

Stanford and University of Washington researchers identified a critical accuracy issue: LLMs exhibit a U-shaped performance curve when processing retrieved context [4]. Performance is highest when relevant information appears at the beginning or end of the context window but degrades by more than 20% when key information falls in the middle. This persists even in models explicitly designed for long-context processing. The root cause traces to rotary position embedding introducing long-term decay that causes models to prioritize tokens at sequence boundaries.

 

Seven Documented Failure Points Reveal Systemic Vulnerabilities

Empirical research identified seven distinct failure modes in RAG systems [5]. Missing content occurs when answers simply don't exist in the knowledge base, yet the system generates plausible-sounding responses. Missed top-ranked documents happen when correct answers exist but don't rank highly enough to be retrieved within the top-K limitation. Consolidation failures arise when retrieved documents don't make it into the final context due to token limits. Extraction failures occur when the LLM fails to identify answers amid noisy or contradicting retrieved content.

 

Implementation Complexity Creates Combinatorial Tuning Challenges

Practitioners face what industry analysts describe as a "combinatorial explosion" of parameters requiring joint optimization: chunk size and overlap, embedding model selection, vector database configuration, top-K retrieval settings, reranking algorithms, context consolidation strategy, and prompt engineering. Finding optimal chunking strategies proves particularly difficult‚Äîchunks that are too small cannot answer certain questions, while chunks that are too large introduce noise.

 

Accuracy Degrades at Scale

Research by EyeLevel.ai found that vector similarity search precision degrades starting at 10,000 pages, with 12% accuracy loss by 100,000 pages [6]. As datastores grow, retrieval throughput can degrade significantly, presenting challenges for enterprise-scale deployments.

 

What is CAG?

Cache-Augmented Generation represents an alternative paradigm that bypasses real-time retrieval entirely. Introduced in December 2024 by Brian Chan, Chao-Ting Chen, Jui-Hung Cheng, and Hen-Hsen Huang in their paper "Don't Do RAG: When Cache-Augmented Generation is All You Need for Knowledge Tasks," [7] CAG leverages the extended context windows of modern LLMs to preload entire knowledge bases rather than retrieving subsets at query time.

 

 

The Three-Phase CAG Workflow

CAG operates through three distinct phases. During knowledge preloading, a curated collection of documents is preprocessed and formatted to fit within the model's context window. The LLM processes this collection, generating a precomputed Key-Value (KV) cache that encapsulates the inference state. This cache is stored persistently on disk or in memory, with computational cost incurred only once regardless of subsequent query volume.

During inference, the precomputed KV cache is loaded alongside each user query. The LLM utilizes this cached context to generate responses directly‚Äîno dynamic document fetching occurs. The combined prompt provides unified understanding of both knowledge and query, enabling the model to reason across the entire knowledge base simultaneously.

The cache reset phase addresses a practical concern: since KV caches grow in an append-only manner as new tokens are generated, resetting involves truncating newly appended tokens to return to the original cached state. This enables rapid reinitialization without reloading the entire cache from disk.

 

Understanding the KV Cache Mechanism

CAG extends the standard KV caching concept by precomputing the entire KV cache for the knowledge base‚Äînot just conversation history‚Äîand storing it persistently. At inference time, loading this pre-computed cache makes the "context" effectively free from a computational perspective. The model treats the entire knowledge base as if it were part of the conversation history, enabling full-context reasoning without retrieval.

 

Model Requirements for CAG Deployment

CAG requires long-context LLMs to be practical. Current frontier models supporting extended contexts include Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro and Flash with 1-2 million token windows, Claude models supporting 200K-1M tokens, GPT-4o with 128K tokens, and open-source options like Llama 3.1 with 128K token support. Research indicates that most models experience performance degradation before reaching advertised limits‚Äîa 128K window typically remains reliable to approximately 100K tokens in practice.

 

How CAG Addresses These Challenges

CAG's architectural simplicity eliminates several of RAG's fundamental pain points while introducing its own trade-offs.

 

Latency Reduction Through Retrieval Elimination

By removing the retrieval pipeline entirely, CAG achieves dramatic latency improvements. The original CAG paper demonstrated generation times of 0.85 seconds versus 9.25 seconds for small HotPotQA datasets‚Äîa 10.9x speedup [7]. For larger datasets (64 documents, 85K tokens), CAG completed in 2.33 seconds compared to 94.35 seconds without caching, representing a 40.5x improvement [7]. These gains come from eliminating query embedding computation, vector similarity search, document reranking, and context packaging steps that dominate RAG latency.

 

Accuracy Improvements from Complete Context Access

CAG consistently achieves higher accuracy than RAG configurations across benchmark datasets. On HotPotQA, CAG achieved BERTScore of 0.7759 versus 0.7516 for the best dense RAG configuration [7]. On SQuAD datasets, CAG scored 0.8265 compared to 0.8035 for dense RAG [7]. The advantage becomes more pronounced for multi-hop reasoning tasks requiring information synthesis across multiple documents‚ÄîCAG has access to all documents simultaneously, while RAG may miss connecting information if the retriever fails to surface relevant chunks.

RAG particularly struggles with queries requiring multi-step reasoning, general queries where formulating retrieval queries is difficult, and implicit queries requiring whole-context understanding.

 

Architectural Simplicity Reduces Failure Modes

CAG eliminates several RAG failure points entirely. There are no retrieval misses because all documents are always present. Chunking strategy optimization becomes unnecessary. Embedding model selection and vector database tuning disappear as concerns. The combinatorial explosion of RAG parameters collapses to a simpler question: does your knowledge fit within the context window? This simplification reduces implementation time, operational complexity, and the surface area for system failures.

 

Side-by-Side Performance Evaluation

Empirical benchmarks reveal that neither approach dominates across all dimensions‚Äîthe optimal choice depends on specific deployment requirements.

CAG

Scalability represents CAG's fundamental constraint. When researchers attempted CAG with 500+ documents on HotPotQA, the system encountered token limit errors [7]. RAG maintains consistent accuracy through selective retrieval regardless of total corpus size, making it the only viable option for enterprise knowledge bases spanning millions of documents.

 

Limitations of CAG

Understanding CAG's constraints is essential for appropriate deployment decisions.

 

Context Window Ceiling Creates Hard Knowledge Limits

Even with models supporting 128K or 1M token contexts, CAG cannot accommodate enterprise-scale knowledge bases. Web-scale corpora like Wikipedia's 3 billion words remain entirely infeasible. A 128K token window accommodates approximately 300 pages of text‚Äîsubstantial for focused applications but insufficient for organizations with multi-terabyte document repositories.

 

Memory and Compute Requirements Are Substantial

The KV cache grows linearly with context length and can exceed the size of model weights themselves at long contexts. Researchers reported that dual A100 40GB GPUs couldn't handle CAG scaling to larger knowledge bases, with the initial loading process proving "extremely memory-intensive." Standard attention has O(n¬≤) complexity, making very long inputs computationally prohibitive. Production deployments often require 8-way tensor parallel setups across multiple GPUs to support both long contexts and reasonable concurrency.

 

Static Knowledge Creates Freshness Challenges

CAG's precomputed cache reflects knowledge at a single point in time. For dynamic domains‚Äînews, market data, legal compliance updates, inventory systems‚Äîcached knowledge becomes stale rapidly. Rebuilding caches for large knowledge bases requires substantial compute overhead, making CAG unsuitable for applications requiring dynamic updates or on-demand knowledge integration.

 

The "Lost in the Middle" Problem Persists

Despite having full context access, CAG inherits the same positional bias affecting all long-context LLM processing. Research confirms that information positioned in the middle of long contexts is more likely to be overlooked or poorly utilized, producing a U-shaped accuracy curve regardless of whether context arrived through retrieval or preloading [4].

 

Hybrid Approaches Combining CAG and RAG

The recognition that neither approach dominates across all scenarios has driven development of hybrid architectures that capture benefits from both paradigms.

 

 

Self-Route Enables Adaptive Query Handling

Research presented at EMNLP 2024 introduced Self-Route, an approach where the LLM self-reflects on whether queries are answerable with RAG alone [8]. The system presents retrieved chunks to the model, which evaluates whether the context is sufficient. If answerable, the system uses the lower-cost RAG response; if insufficient, it escalates to full long-context processing. For Gemini-1.5-Pro, 81.74% of queries were answered by RAG without escalation, achieving performance comparable to full long-context processing while using only 38.6% of tokens [8].

 

Tiered Architectures Serve Diverse Query Patterns

Organizations are implementing tiered systems that route queries based on characteristics. Core, frequently-accessed knowledge is preloaded via CAG for instant response times. Extended or dynamic knowledge is served through RAG with real-time retrieval. A retail example preloads product specifications via CAG for customer support while using RAG to fetch current promotions or inventory status. This architecture balances the efficiency of preloading with the flexibility of retrieval, enabling sub-second responses for common queries while maintaining access to the full knowledge corpus.

 

Foundation Context with Selective Retrieval

The original CAG paper proposed systems that "preload a foundation context and use retrieval only to augment edge cases or highly specific queries" [7]. This balances efficiency with flexibility‚Äîstable knowledge lives in the cache while the retrieval system handles novel or specialized information needs. The RAPTOR approach extends this by clustering documents into topics, generating high-level summaries for each cluster, caching summaries in the CAG layer, and fetching full documents on demand when deeper detail is required [9].

 

Conclusion

The emergence of Cache-Augmented Generation challenges assumptions that have dominated knowledge-augmented AI development since 2020. For applications with manageable, stable knowledge requirements where latency matters, CAG offers a compelling alternative: 10-40x faster generation times, 2-4% higher accuracy, and dramatically simpler architecture compared to RAG. The elimination of retrieval pipelines removes entire categories of failure modes that have frustrated enterprise deployments.

Yet RAG remains indispensable for the majority of production use cases. When knowledge bases span millions of documents, when information changes frequently, or when source attribution is required, RAG's selective retrieval approach proves essential.

The most significant development is the maturation of hybrid architectures that transcend the binary choice. Self-Route and similar approaches demonstrate that intelligent query routing can achieve long-context performance while using only 38.6% of tokens [8]. Tiered systems that combine CAG's speed for core knowledge with RAG's flexibility for extended corpora represent a practical path forward for organizations with diverse query patterns.

For data scientists evaluating these approaches, the decision framework has clarified: assess knowledge base size, update frequency, and latency requirements. Knowledge bases under 100K tokens with infrequent updates are strong CAG candidates. Enterprise-scale deployments with dynamic knowledge require RAG. Most organizations will benefit from hybrid architectures that route queries to the appropriate system based on complexity and freshness requirements.

entry.title: The Hidden Behavior of LLMs - Prompt Caching and Determinism
entry.content:
The Hidden Behavior of LLMs - The LLM Prompt Caching and Determinism
Are LLMs Really Stateless?

A Developer‚Äôs Deep Dive Into the Hidden Behavior of LLMs (with code-gen as the use case)

Introduction: The "Wait, What?" Moment

I recently started building a code generation tool using Large Language Models (LLMs) via API calls. Like many of you, I learned the golden rule of LLM development early on: LLMs are stateless. They don‚Äôt "remember" past requests; every API call is a fresh start.

But as I tested my tool, I noticed something that confused me.

  1. Whenever I made changes in my prompt instructions: The output was perfect!
  2. When I changed nothing and sent the exact same request: The output still changed!

I expected that if the inputs were identical (and the model is stateless), the result should be consistent. This inconsistency led me down a rabbit hole of research where I landed on a feature that completely changed how I optimize my workflows: Prompt Caching.

If you are building AI Agents or Code Gen tools on SAP BTP (using SAP Generative AI Hub) or directly via provider APIs, this is a mechanism you need to understand‚Äînot just for speed, but to clear up the "caching" misconception.

The Myth Buster: "Prompt Cache" NE "Response Cache"

Here is the inference I made during my research, which might clear up your confusion too:

The Reality: Prompt Caching does not cache the answer. It caches the question.

When we hear "Cache" in software development (like SAP ABAP or SAP HANA), we think of storing the result to serve it instantly next time. Prompt Caching is different. It caches the pre-computation of your input context (the Key-Value states of the attention mechanism). It essentially "pre-loads" the model's brain with your long documents, codebases, or instructions.

However, the generation of the response is still calculated fresh, token by token. This brings us to the second major realization‚Äîwhy your output changes even when the prompt doesn't.

The "Temperature=0" Trap: Why It‚Äôs Still Not Deterministic

You might think, "If the prompt is cached and I set Temperature to 0, shouldn't the output be identical every time?"

The short answer: No.

The technical answer: Modern LLMs are only "mostly" deterministic, even at Temperature=0.

While setting the temperature to 0 forces greedy decoding (always picking the highest-probability next token), real-world infrastructure introduces subtle variations:

  1. Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) Architecture: Models like GPT-4 are believed to use a "Sparse MoE" design. Different "expert" subnetworks handle different parts of your input. Parallel routing and slight gating differences can introduce non-determinism in the path your data takes.
  2. GPU "Fuzziness": Modern GPUs perform massive parallel operations. Because floating-point arithmetic is non-associative, the order of operations can shift slightly based on thread scheduling. A microscopic rounding error can flip a token choice when two words have nearly identical probabilities.
  3. System Variance: Your request might hit a different backend instance or hardware generation (indicated by the system_fingerprint in OpenAI responses).

The Takeaway: Even with a cached prompt and zero temperature, expect minor "drift" in your outputs. The prompt cache speeds up the input processing, but the output generation remains subject to the complex physics of AI hardware.

How It Works: Implicit vs. Explicit

Different vendors handle this differently. If you are using models via SAP Generative AI Hub, it's crucial to know how the underlying models behave.

Implicit Caching (The "It Just Works" Approach)

Vendors: OpenAI (GPT-4.1), Google (Gemini)

  • Mechanism: You don't need to change your code. If the API detects that the first 1,024+ tokens of your prompt match a previous request sent recently, it automatically uses the cached processing.
  • Pros: Zero developer effort.
  • Cons: Less control over what stays in the cache.

Explicit Caching (The "Precision" Approach)

Vendor: Anthropic (Claude 3.5 and > Sonnet/Haiku)

  • Mechanism: You must explicitly tell the API where to stop caching. You insert a cache_control parameter at a specific "checkpoint" in your message history.
  • Pros: You guarantee that your heavy context (like a full ABAP codebase or API specification) is cached.
  • Cons: Requires a small code change.

A Common Practice for Agentic AI & Code Gen

In my code generation use case, I send the entire project context (libraries, style guides, and current code) with every request. Without caching, this is slow and expensive.

The Strategy:

Organize your prompt so the static content is at the top.

  1. System Prompt (Static: "You are an ABAP Expert...")
  2. Context/Documentation (Static: "Here is the SAP Cloud SDK documentation...") -> [CACHE CHECKPOINT]
  3. User Query (Dynamic: "Write a method to fetch Business Partners.")

By placing the checkpoint after the documentation, the model "reads" the docs once. For every subsequent user query, it skips the heavy lifting and jumps straight to generating code.

Verifying the Speed Up: Analyze Your Logs

How do you know it's working? You won't see "same output," but you will see "faster time-to-first-token."

Look at the usage metadata in your API response.

  • OpenAI: Look for cached_tokens in the usage object.
  • Anthropic: Look for cache_read_input_tokens.
  • Google Gemini: Look for cachedContentTokenCount.

Example Analysis:

  • Request 1 (Cold): Input Tokens: 10,000 | Processing Time: 4.5s
  • Request 2 (Warm): Input Tokens: 10,000 (9,900 Cached!) | Processing Time: 0.8s

Why could this be a game-changer?

  • Latency: The model doesn't have to "read" your 5,000-line code file every time. It "remembers" the reading process.
  • Cost: You pay significantly less (often ~90% less) for the cached tokens.

If you see the processing time drop drastically while the output remains high-quality (and slightly varied), you have successfully implemented Prompt Caching.

My Personal Inference: The "Bad Roll" & The Butterfly Effect

During my testing, I encountered a frustrating scenario that I believe many developers will face.

  • The Scenario: I used OpenAI for code generation. When the prompt was cached (no changes), the code quality was consistently "not perfect"‚Äîit had minor bugs or incomplete logic.
  • The Fix: When I added just one single word to the prompt, the code generation suddenly became perfect.
  • The Contrast: Switching to Anthropic (without caching) gave me complete code every time.

Why did adding one word fix the OpenAI output? This is what I call the "Deterministic Trap." When you use a cached prompt with a low temperature (which we usually do for code), the model is mathematically locked into a specific "reasoning path." If the model generates a suboptimal solution (a "bad roll") on the first try, the cached state ensures it starts from the exact same mathematical position next time. It essentially "remembers" the path to the bad answer.

By adding a single word, I forced a "Cache Miss" (or at least a perturbation in the attention mechanism). This acted like the "Butterfly Effect"‚Äîit shifted the token probabilities just enough to force the model to calculate a fresh path, allowing it to escape the "bad roll" and find the correct solution.

The Lesson: Prompt Caching is powerful for speed, but if you notice your model is "stuck" giving you the same bad code repeatedly, don't just retry. Change the prompt. Even a single extra adjective can shake the model out of a local minimum and produce the perfect result.

Conclusion

LLMs are stateless, but Prompt Caching gives them a "short-term memory" for processing inputs. While it won't force your outputs to be bit-for-bit identical (due to MoE and GPU nuances), it will make your applications significantly faster and cheaper to run.

Next Step: Check your current API logs. If you are sending long contexts (>1024 tokens) repeatedly, you might already be benefiting from implicit caching, or you may need to add cache_control headers for Anthropic models to unlock these savings.

References & Further Reading

  • Anthropic Prompt Caching: (https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/prompt-caching)
  • OpenAI Prompt Caching: (https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/prompt-caching)
  • Google Gemini Context Caching: (https://ai.google.dev/gemini-api/docs/caching)
  • SAP Generative AI Hub: (https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-ai-core/generative-ai-hub)

entry.title: SAP Translation Hub rolls out term-aware post-editing of AI translated content
entry.content:
Machine translation is a practical tool for organizations managing software localization at scale. However, a common challenge is that standard translation engines tend to produce generic output that doesn‚Äôt account for terminology that is specific to an organization, a brand or an industry. This means that product names, unique UI labels, and industry-specific terms often require manual correction after the initial translation, creating additional work in the post-editing phase.

To address this workflow challenge, SAP Translation Hub now offers term-aware translation as part of our Intelligent Data Reuse component. This capability is designed to incorporate your custom glossaries directly into the AI translation process, both with SAP neural machine translation as well as with our LLM-based translation provider.

 

How term-aware translation works

The feature operates through a straightforward mechanism:

  • Define Your terminology:
    You begin by creating a multilingual file that contains terms specific to your organization, such as product names, UI labels, and industry jargon that require consistent translation.
  • Activate the glossary:
    Once you have defined your terminology, you upload it to Intelligent Data Reuse in SAP Translation Hub and activate your glossary.
  • AI-translate your content leveraging your terminology:
    Add your glossary ID to your API call and the approved translations will be applied.

 

Practical Benefits

This approach delivers several concrete advantages for your localization workflow:

  • Lower post-editing volume:
    Because fewer terminology corrections are required after the AI translation is complete, you can focus on other tasks.
  • Consistent terminology:
    Your approved terms will appear consistently across all translated content, reducing variation within a translation project, and across translation projects    .
  • Predictable output:
    The system applies your glossaries systematically, which makes the translation results more predictable and easier to quality-assure.
  • Faster turnaround:
    With less manual correction work needed, your translation cycles can move more quickly through the post-editing phase.

 

Demo

 

 

 

 

 

Watch the recorded demo to see term-aware translation in practice.

 

Implementation Considerations

Term-aware translation works best when your glossaries are well-maintained and contain terms that are actually present in your source content. The overall effectiveness of the feature depends on how comprehensively your glossaries cover the key terminology in your materials.

Please refer to SAP Translation Hub's Document Translation and Intelligent Data Reuse documentation on SAP Help Portal for more details.

If you have any questions about term-aware translation or about creating and maintaining glossaries to get the most out of this feature, comment below or reach out to translationhub@sap.com.
